titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Stage at 6 O’Clock for Baltimore— There was a Mr and Mrs White in it— English-born, but residing at Georgetown— At Brown’s Hotel we took in, Mr Blake of New-York, and at Miss Hyer’s a Mrs Bell, wife of an Officer in the Navy, and daughter of the late Genl. John Swartwout of New-York. We breakfasted at Ross’s, and reached Baltimore about 2. P.M. Stopped at Barney’s tavern; called the Fountain Inn— Found Johnson Hellen there; who shewed me a Letter from Miss Carey— A parting one; in unwilling submission to the prejudices of her mother— I dined at the public Table, and then went with Johnson to view the Washington and Battle Monuments, and the Roman Catholic Cathedral. Returning, I met Mr Isaac Munro and Coll. Bentalou, the Marshal of the District, who accompanied me to the City Hall and Exchange. Where preparations are making for the reception of Genl. La Fayette.— A large Hall is also preparing at Barney’s, where a public dinner is to be given him by the Corporation— At 5. in the afternoon I repaired to the new Steam-Boat, Constitution Captain Robertson. Mr Niles, Mr Glenn, two Williams’s and several other persons came and greeted me at the Steam-boat until its departure. The weather was fine; the Sea Smooth, and about half past eleven at Night we landed at Frenchtown.

2.— Proceeded immediately in the Stage, and at four in the Morning arrived at Newcastle. There took the Steam-boat Baltimore, Captain Davis, for Philadelphia, which we reached at eight— I left my baggage to be transferred to the Boat, that was to go at Noon for Trenton. Called at S. Ewing’s house; but he was gone to the Yellow Springs; having previously been to
Saratoga— His health much impaired. I then called at Mr Jos. Hopkinson’s— He determined to go with me to Bordentown— Mr Hall Ewing’s uncle was with him. I called on Mr Walsh at his Office, and then, at Mr. John Sergeant’s, with whom I found Mr Yard— Saw Mrs Sergeant also— Thence I went to the Bank of the United States, and saw the President N. Biddle— He accompanied me to the Steam-boat Philadelphia, which I very narrowly missed by being too late— The boat stopped on the left shore of the Delaware, and landed the passengers who were going by the way of Trenton— And there I parted from my fellow passengers Mr Blake of New-York and Mrs Bell— About 5. I landed in a boat with Mr Hopkinson at Bordentown; the shallowness of the river at low-tide not admitting the Boat to reach the wharf— At Mr Hopkinson’s I found Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen— Miss Mease was also there— Walk with Mr Hopkinson round his grounds— Evening pleasantly past, though with a cast of gloom at the distress of Mrs Keating, Mr Hopkinson’s daughter; who was married very happily last Spring; and whose husband died a few weeks after the marriage— An affecting instance of the vicissitudes and disappointments of human life— We retired early for the Night.

3. VII.Mrs Adams concluded to go with me to Quincy: and we took the Stage for Brunswick at ten this morning—distance 28 miles. We arrived at Brunswick at 3 in the afternoon, Steam-boat Legislature. Followed immediately by the Thistle; of the opposition line— There was a great crowd of Passengers, and the deck was covered with barrels and baskets of peaches; going to the New-York market. Among the passengers were several who recognized me; and the market-man, insisted upon my accepting two or three of his peaches as a brother yankee— He told me his name was Barrett— That he came from Vermont, and his father had been of Boston. Mr. Dufief the author of the Grammar and Dictionary, likewise recognized, and spoke to me. There was a race between the two boats; and in the narrowest parts of the Rariton river, for about half an hour the bow of the Thistle, was within ten feet of our Stern, both going at a rate of at least ten miles an hour. As soon as there was width of passage for both Boats, the Thistle passed us and reached New-York before us a few minutes. We landed about 7. in the Evening, and came to the City-Hotel.— From the competition between the two lines, the fare between Philadelphia and New-York is reduced to 2 dollars and the passage from Brunswick to N.Y. to 12.1/2 cents.

4. VI:30. Rainy, sultry Night. Morning absorbed by visitors— C. King brought me a manuscript copy of three Letters written by me in 1808 and 1809. to a member of Congress. He said they had been sent to him for publication in the New-York American; but he knew not to whom they were written; nor from whom they came.— I told him they were genuine, and I believed were to Mr Ezekiel Bacon; who was at that time a member of Congress from Massachusetts. Mr Mower called and gave me a pamphlet published this morning by M. M. Noah late Editor of the National Advocate; the proprietors of which have quarreled among themselves— Other visitors were judge and Mrs Thompson. Mrs. and then Commodore Stewart, Mr Wheaton—judge Ogden Edwards, Mr Bailey the Postmaster, R. Swartwout, and Mr M’Cormick. Swartwout was desirous that I should stop two or three days in the City: and as I could not, desired me to ask Mr Southard to stop, on his return to Washington— Judge Thompson spoke of a misunderstanding between him, and the District judge Van Ness, about the place where the Circuit Court should be held in the City of New-York, and in consequence of which the Court this week has been held by Van Ness alone; and that no business has been done— The visitors engrossed all the morning till dinner, immediately after which we embarked, at 3. O’Clock, in the Steam-boat Fulton Captain Comstock. The boat is crowded with Passengers among whom are Mrs D’Wolfe, wife of the Senator from Rhode-Island, and her daughters Mrs Dodge and Mrs Perry; two of her Sons, and one of her Grand-children— Mr Gerry Fairbanks of Boston; a man, wife, and several children by the name of Page; just from Russia, where Page who is an American, married his wife, who is of an English family there— Coll. Henderson, with two of his wife’s Sisters, Mrs Hall and Miss Cazenave and Mr Brown, a Clerk in the Department of State— Mrs D’Wolfe, and her daughters came on board from a place near Sands’s point. The evening was fair, and I sat up on deck till near Midnight; expecting to meet the Steam-boat Oliver Ellsworth, from Hartford, in which General La Fayette, was returning to New-York— In this I was disappointed, and finally retired to a birth in the forward Cabin, which Mr Fairbanks insisted, upon giving up to me.

5. VI. On rising this morning I found we were just outside of the Southern extremity of Fisher’s Island; with fair weather, but a very heavy swell, and the boat rolling, more than I had ever before experienced in a Steam-boat. Many of the Passengers became Sea-sick— None of the Ladies came out to breakfast; and the swell and rolling continued until we had passed the Lighthouse, six miles below Newport— We reached the City about 11 in the morning. Mrs Hall, Miss Cazenave and several
other passengers landed there— At half past one we touched at Bristol, and there landed Mrs D’Wolfe and her family— Mrs Dodge was of the party— At three in the afternoon we landed at Providence being precisely 24 hours from New-York— Just before we landed I was requested to step down from the deck, into the forward Cabin, where I found almost all of the men passengers assembled, and Mr Fairbanks announced to me a complimentary Resolution to me with a request that I would take a glass of wine with them— I accepted their invitation, returned them my thanks for their kindness; and shook hands with them, all round. We immediately landed, and took Stages for Boston. Supped about nine at Fuller’s in Walpole; and arrived at Hamilton’s Exchange Coffee House about one in the Morning— There was a light rain during the ride from Dedham— Mrs Adams much fatigued.

6. VII. Heavy Thunder shower in the night, within an hour after we were housed— This morning immediately after rising I called at Dr Welsh’s. Saw only Mrs Welsh. My Son George had passed the Sunday at my father’s at Quincy— Mr Edward Cruft called immediately— Then Joseph Hall, the Sheriff— George came in after breakfast from Quincy. We had calls from Messrs. Wallenstein and Ticknor— A. H. Everett— William Gray— Coll. Harris, Dr Waterhouse, and Harriet Welsh— At about eleven we took a Hack, and came out with George to my father’s House at Quincy. I found my Son Charles here; it being vacation time at Cambridge. Mr Degrand came out in the Evening. The infirmities of age have much increased upon my father since I was here last year— His sight is so dim that he can neither write nor read— He cannot walk without aid; and his hearing is partially affected— His memory yet remains strong; his judgment sound; and his interest in conversation considerable.

7. VII.George returned this morning to Boston in the Stage. We had visits from General H. Dearborn, A. H. and Edward Everett, and their Ladies— Edward Everett gave me a copy of his ΦBK. Oration, delivered at Cambridge the day after Commencement, which is highly celebrated. We went into Boston. Stopped at Governor Eustis’s and saw Mrs Eustis. He was not at home. At Boston we alighted at Mr Cruft’s. I called at the Athenaeum. Dined at George Blake’s— Mrs Elwyn, Mr. and Mrs Crofts of Charleston S.C. Mr and Mrs Webster—and Mr Edward Everett were there. In the Evening we returned to Quincy, taking George with us. Mrs Adams dined at Mr Cruft’s.

8. VI. Passed the day at Quincy. Heavy rain, great part of the day— Messrs. Norton, Southard, with Commodores Chauncey and Morris and Dr Harris, Governor and Mrs Eustis, visited us. I had a particular conversation with Mr Southard, and told him what R. Swartwout had said to me at New-York— Southard is going to-morrow to Portsmouth, to return the next day. The remainder of this day I passed in Conversations with my father. He bears his condition with fortitude; but is sensible to all its helplessness. His mind is still vigorous; but cannot dwell long upon any one subject— Articles of news, and of political speculation in the Newspapers are read to him; on which he remarks with sound discernment— He receives some Letters, and dictates answers to them— In general the most remarkable circumstance of his present state, is the total prostration of his physical powers, leaving his mental faculties scarcely impaired at-all. Mr Degrand came out and spent the Evening here.

9. V:45. I took a ride of about three miles with my father in his small carriage— Called at Mr Marston’s, and rode to the foot of Penn’s Hill, by the houses where my father, and myself were born— That of his nativity, has within the last year at his request been painted white— General H. A. S. Dearborn came out from Boston, for a Committee of several persons who at a private meeting resolved to give me a great Public Dinner at Faneuil Hall— I desired Genl. Dearborn to return my thanks to the Meeting for the intended honour, and assure them of the grateful sense I entertain of their kindness— But to say that in the present agitation of the public mind; in the divisions of sentiment prevailing, and in the total uncertainty of their issue; this measure would probably increase the excitement which should rather be allayed— It might have the aspect of a political expedient to make an ostentious and equivocal exhibition of popularity, and perhaps even be represented as gotten up, my own desire for that purpose— That I begged therefore to decline this testimonial of their friendship, with the assurance that my sense of obligation to those by whom it was offered was warm as if it had been accepted— I went in to Boston with Mrs Adams. Stopped on the way at Governor Eustis’s; and had half an hour’s Conversation with him. He spoke of the Massachusetts claim upon the Government of the United States with great solicitude; and thinking it just, I told him I should give it all the aid in my power. He spoke also of the electoral ticket in this State— A ticket was nominated by the republican members of the Legislature last June, understood to be favourable to me— An opposition ticket has since been gotten up, at the head of which they have placed the names of Eustis, and of the late Governor Brooks— As this opposition has not been countenanced
by either of them, they have been urged by their friends to decline publicly, and Eustis told me that they would— He said the only question was as to the time, and he believed that would be soon. His own opinion, he said had been made up and declared, two years ago; and it was well known not only here but at New-York and Albany— He would see Brooks, and they would decline about the same time, though perhaps not by a joint act. In Boston I called at Mr Cruft’s, found George there; and Mrs Hall— Then went to Mr W: Sturgis’s, but he was not at home—to James H. Foster’s, and saw him and his family— To Stewart the Painter’s—but he was gone to Cambridge— Dined at Mr G. Ticknor’s with a small party. Judge Story. Mr W. Prescott and his Sons. Mr Webster. A. H. Everett. Powell Mason— Wallenstein and W. Elliot were there— Mr Quincy came in after dinner— Judge Story invited me to dine with him at Salem, and to give him notice of the day when I could come; which I promised to do— We returned in the Evening to Quincy, and attended an evening party at Mrs Quincy’s. Mrs Storer was there; at an age nearly equal to that of my father— Home about eleven O’Clock.

10. VI:30. Visit from Captain Benjamin Beale, my father’s next door neighbour, aged 84. General W. H. Sumner came and invited me to dine with him at Dorchester. He gave me the manuscripts of several papers written by me in the year 1804 and then published in the Repertory. Mr G. Beale, Mr and Mrs T. Greenleaf, Judge Davis and Mr W. Sturgis, came out in the course of the morning. I dined with W. H. Sumner, at a small neat pavilion, where he resides at Dorchester— Governor Eustis, and B. Joy were the only company. R. G. Amory came in after dinner. Very warm political conversation, between Eustis and Amory— Mrs Adams came and took me up after dinner, and we went in to Boston to an Evening party at Mr Saml. P. Gardner’s— The rooms were crowded, and the heat almost stifling— Mr Gardner married a Sister of the Lowell family; and he is connected with the Cabot, Williams and Pickering families— But his daughter married Mr William Gray’s son John— The company this Evening was accordingly a political medley— I left Mrs Adams to Lodge at Mr Cruft’s, and came alone home to my father’s

11. VII.Mr Norton of Weymouth came to see me. He is about removing to the State of Vermont, and offers me for Sale, the house and Estate where he now lives in Weymouth; being that where my mother was born, and where some of the earliest years of my childhood were past— I told him that I had strong temptations to purchase it, but could not without great inconvenience, and must therefore decline it— But I agreed to take his Potowmack Bridge Stock, as had been proposed to me by judge Cranch.
I went into Boston— Called at Stewart the Painter’s— He promised to finish the Portrait of my father which he painted for me last year, but which was not then completed— He has also an excellent Portrait of Mr W. N. Boylston, which he painted some weeks since at Princeton, and of which I bespoke a copy— I visited also Mr Southard, and Commodores Chauncey and Morris at the Marlborough Hotel— Southard is obliged to leave Boston, upon his return towards Washington next Tuesday— Visits to Mr William Gray, and his Son Francis. Return to Mr Cruft’s. Dined at General H. Dearborn’s— Govr. Eustis, Mr Wingate of Portland, G. Blake, J. T. Austin, Mr Winthrop and their Ladies were there. Also Mr Melville, the naval Officers Genl. and Mrs H. A. S. Dearborn, Coll. Harris, and John Everett, and my Son George, who returned with us in the Evening to Quincy.

12. VI:30. Heard Mr Huntoon of Canton from Galatians 6.4. [“]But let every man prove his own work, and then shall he have rejoicing in himself alone, and not in another.”— And from Matthew 11.13. [“]For all the prophets and the law prophesied until John.” Mr Huntoon dined with us; and also Mr Degrand who came out from Boston— After the afternoon service I walked over the hills with Degrand to the summit of the Granite rock, whence the fine prospect of the harbour and Bay is seen. They are cutting away the rock to build up the streets of Boston. While we were out Mr Webster called at my father’s, but did not stay till my return— Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf and Mr Edward Miller, passed the Evening here.

13. V:30. Went in to Boston early this morning with George— Fishing party, in the Revenue Cutter, Captain Trevett— Our party consisted of Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn, William Sturgis, Mr Cruft, and my son George— We went on board about nine in the morning; but the day was calm, so that it was with great difficulty that we got out of the harbour— About 2 in the afternoon we took the boat and boarded a Sloop, fishing, about a mile off Nahant; where we purchased some fish; about 3 the Cutter came up with us, and it began to rain— We fished about an hour, without much success— I caught one Cod, and one Mackerel, with a Cod hook— The largest I ever saw— Dined upon Chowder. The calm continued, and as we were returning, the tide came against us just after we passed the Lighthouse, and between the outer revolving and long-island lights we came to anchor, for about three hours— About ten in the Evening we got under weigh again, and landed between the central and long wharfs at Midnight— General Dearborn immediately went out to Roxbury; and I came home to lodge at Mr Cruft’s— George went to Dr Welsh’s. I had intended to have returned this Evening to Quincy, but when we got back to Boston, it was too late.

14. VII. After breakfast at Mr Cruft’s I came out to Quincy alone. I had with me a small manuscript Volume; being the Journal kept by my mother, when she went to England, in June 1784—and with fragments of a diary while she was there, until her departure in 1788 to return home. The perusal of it, brought many pleasing and mournful recollections to my mind— On my reaching home, a Mr Baker came, and took a miniature likeness of me in wax— It was hideous— Mr Israel Hatch of Attleborough came to ask a Letter to the Postmaster General. He is going to Washington to apply for a contract to carry the Mail— Visits to Mrs Adams from Miss Ellen Davis, and another young Lady— I went to Cambridge with Mrs Adams and we took Charles with us— We left him at his room, and dined at Professor Everett’s— Mr Southard, Commodore Chauncey, Mr. and Mrs Webster, Mr P. C. Brooks, Mr and Mrs A. H. Everett, and my Son George were of the party— We returned in the Evening through Boston to Quincy, and found Mrs Marston, and Mr and Mrs John Greenleaf at my father’s.

15. V:30. Bath at Black’s wharf. Half-tide— After Breakfast rode with my father— To Mr Marston’s— To H. Hardwick’s, to Mount Wollaston, and as far as Mr Spear’s house— The ride was rather too long for my father’s feeble state at this time— We had visits from Mrs E. H. Robbins, Mr. and Mrs Lyman, and Mr and Miss Gerry— Mrs Adams went to Boston, to Dr Welsh’s. I dined with my brother at Governor Eustis’s at Roxbury— Mrs T. B. Adams went with us, as far as a Mr Lunt’s, a neighbour of the Governor’s. The dinner, was of men only—a company of about forty, variously assorted, and with toasts— I escaped as soon as I could; and came out with Mr Quincy; who took me to my father’s— George had been of the dinner, and also came out in the Evening— Quincy spoke to me confidentially, respecting the state and prospects of my father’s health. He wrote under my father’s dictation, his Will, and is appointed joint-Executor of it with myself— I have not seen it— I have hope that my personal attentions may yet contribute to the comfort of his declining days; and with gratitude to Providence observe the still vigorous energies of his mind. Mrs Adams remained this Night at Boston.

16. V:15. Bath with George at the wharf— Mr and Mrs Norton of Weymouth called at my father’s— I took his Potowmack-Bridge Stock, for which he gave me an order upon judge Cranch. I went into Boston with George. Met Messrs.Barstow and Stephen White of Salem, and Mr. B. Gorham with another friend, who were going out to visit me at Quincy. I promised Mr White to spend the Evening with him at Salem next
Wednesday. I had written to judge Story; engaging to dine with him on that day. I called at Mr Stewart the Painter’s, and found that he had worked at my father’s Portrait since I last saw it; and he promised to go out to Quincy one day next week to finish it— At Mr Cruft’s I met Mrs Adams, and we had visits there, from Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn, Messrs. Crowninshield (who engaged me to lodge at his house next Wednesday[)]. Shepherd, S. A. Welles, and D. D. Rogers— I called at Mr John Brazer’s, and saw there his daughter, Miss Brazer, and his Granddaughter Miss Glover— He was not at home— Met Mrs Bailey in Cornhill— Visits at Mr. Jos. Hall’s, and at Mrs Welsh’s, where I saw Miss Pearce. At the Marlborough Hotel, I found Mr Bailey, and met Mr Rankin of Mississippi— We dined at Mr T. L. Winthrop’s, with a company of both sexes— Governor Eustis was of the party— Somewhat annoyed with a Cannonade Salute from a military Company on the Common, which had been exhibiting to him in the Morning. In the Evening returned to Mr Cruft’s, and saw there Mrs Smith, and Mr Cook the lawyer— We came out to Quincy without George— Mr Hall the Sheriff was at Mr Winthrop’s this day before dinner— Eustis sent for him; to make some arrangement, about his and Brooks’s declining to run upon the unpledged Electoral ticket.

17. VI. Bath at the wharve’s alone— Rainy morning. I passed it chiefly in conversation with my father— Visit from a Mr Vernon of New-York— A nephew of W. H. Vernon of Rhode-Island, who went with us to France in the Boston Frigate in 1778— He has been now living upwards of twenty years in Newport, and his nephew says is a Connoisseur in painting, and has a collection of pictures. He was one of the deputation lately sent from Newport, to invite General La Fayette to that place, and who came to him, to Boston— Dined with Mrs Adams at Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn’s at Roxbury. Company of both sexes. 24. Governor Eustis unwell, and not there. George was of the party, and returned with us in the Evening to Quincy.

18. VI. Change of weather, from sultry to cold. Bath at the wharf alone. With Mrs Adams and George into Boston— Call at Stewart the Painter’s. He has not finished my father’s picture; but will go out one day next week to take a last sitting. I returned the visit of Mr Eustaphieff, the Russian Consul, and saw him; his wife and daughter, who are English. Then at Russell Sturgis’s— At Mr Webster’s Office; which I found as nearly as possible on the same spot, where I kept mine in the years 1792, 1793, and 1794. But the house, then standing there has been pulled down,
and a brick one built in its place— Mr Webster was gone out of town— I called also at Mr James Lloyd’s, but it being his dining hour did not go in— Met Dr Welsh in the street, and called at his house. Dined with Williams Sturgis— Judge and Isaac P. Davis, N. Thorndike, N. Bowditch, and Mr Gould were there— In the Evening I went to Mrs William Smith’s, and found my wife there— We returned with George, to my father’s.

19. VI. Cold bath. The last for the Season— Heard Mr Lamson from Dedham. From Matthew 24.35. “Heaven and Earth shall pass away; but my words shall not pass away.” and from Acts 20.24. “But none of these things move me, neither count I my life dear unto myself, so that I might finish my course with joy, and the ministry, which I have received of the Lord Jesus, to testify the gospel of the grace of God.” Visits after the services, from Mr Lamson, the two Sons of Mr C. Bulfinch who are here on a tour from Washington, and Mr Marston— Mr Joseph E. Sprague, and Degrand came out from Boston; took tea and supped here— I had a long conversation with Sprague on the subject of the Vice-Presidency. With regard to General Jackson, as the prospect now is that he will stand the highest on the list of Candidates for the Presidency, it appears useless to sustain him for the second Office— But as the Pennsylvania nomination, Jackson and Calhoun, is absolute proscription of New-England, I advised Sprague, that my friends here should bethink themselves twice, before they lend their aid to any part of this inveterate exclusion of themselves.

20. VI:15.George went to Boston in the Stage— Mrs Adams was very unwell, and confined to her chamber— I walked in the burying-yard and viewed, the Granite Tombstones, erected over the graves of my ancestors, by my father— Henry Adams, the first of the family who came from England— Joseph Adams Senior, and Abigail Baxter his wife. Joseph Adams junior and Hannah Bass, his second wife— John Adams, senior my father’s father, and Susanna Boylston his wife— Four Generations; of whom very little more is known than is recorded upon these Stones. There are three succeeding Generations of us, now living— Pass another century, and we shall all be mouldering in the same dust, or resolved into the same elements— Who then of our posterity shall visit this yard?— And what shall he read engraved upon the Stones?— This is known only to the Creator of all— The record may be longer—may it be of as blameless lives.
I went and dined at Mr R. G. Amory’s at Dorchester; with a company of about twenty Ladies and Gentlemen— Governor and Mrs Eustis, Mr and Mrs R. Derby— Mr and Mrs Bethune— Mr and Mrs Freeman. Miss Catherine Russell— Coll. Beckwith of the British army. Mr Baring— Mr Joseph Russell— Mr A. H. Everett. My brother and my Son George— Also, a Mr Howland, of Boston— After dinner there came a Miss Tucker, inquisitive about my Son John— There was conversation about the battle of Waterloo, in which Governor Eustis and Coll. Beckwith took part— George returned with me in the Evening to Quincy; and we stopped to a numerous party, at Mr T. Greenleaf’s— Home between ten and eleven.

21. VI:Mrs Adams continues very unwell. Sleepless Night— But she was able to go with me in to Boston— I called at Stewart the Painter’s, and he promised to go to-morrow to my father’s, and take the last sitting for his Portrait— I had made an appointment to meet Mr Webster; but before the time he was obliged to go out of town, and I missed seeing him— Call at T. Fuller’s Office, and had a long conversation with him— He declines a re-election to the next Congress. I mentioned to him in confidence the despatch received from R. Rush, enclosing a proposal from the Greek Agents in London, that the United States should take the Greeks under their Protection— We dined at Mr Joseph Hall; the Sheriff’s. Govr. and Mrs Eustis, the late Governor Brooks, Coll. Trumbull, and Mr & Mrs A. H. Everett were of the party— Numerous Evening party at Governor Eustis’s, Roxbury; and we lodge there— George went out to Quincy.

22. VII. There had been some question; whether Mrs Eustis, and Mrs Adams should go with us to Salem, but they were both this morning too unwell. Mrs Adams concluded therefore to return to Quincy; and Mrs Eustis to remain at home— I came with Governor Eustis’s, through Boston to Salem; and we stopped at the La Fayette, formerly called the Essex Coffee-house. On the road we had Conversation upon various subjects; and the Governor told me many occurrences of his own History. He spoke with great bitterness of H. G. Otis, the rival candidate against him last year for the Office of Governor; and who although he declined standing as a Candidate this year, wrote a series of papers just as the Election was coming on, against Eustis, and in defence of the Hartford Convention— We had also some discussion upon the Powers of the Congress of the United States to institute and establish a system of internal improvement by roads and Canals— The Governor thinks Congress have not this power; and that the exercise of it will be pernicious and perhaps fatal to the Union; upon all which points my opinion is the reverse of his—but we discussed the question with great coolness and good humor— At Salem I called upon my old friend, Coll. B. Pickman, whom I found in great affliction; one of his daughters having
become insane— We dined at judge Story’s— Conversation at dinner on parties— After dinner we visited at Mr N. Silsbee’s, and then spent the Evening at Mr Stephen White’s, where there was very numerous company of Ladies— To almost all the company I was an entire Stranger, but among them there were a Son and daughter of my old Associate and Classmate, judge Putnam. The Governor passed the night at Mr White’s— I came with my Son George and we lodge at Mr B. W. Crowninshield’s.

23. VI:30. We breakfasted with a company of about twenty at Mr G. Barstow’s; who was a member of the last Congress. Then we rode over to Marblehead. Several of the Gentlemen from Salem accompanied us— At Marblehead we met a number of the principal inhabitants of the Town— W. B. Adams, Prince, Hooper’s and others— We visited the Fort. I had never been at this place before; but seemed to recollect the ledges of rocks off the harbour, as I had seen them from the Boston Frigate in February 1778— From Marblehead we came to Commodore Bainbridge’s at the Navy-Yard, Charlestown where I had engaged to dine— The Commodore shewed me the yard, and the line of battle ship now on the Stocks, and a Salute was fired in the yard. The Columbus is also there; laid up, in ordinary— We dined at Commodore Bainbridge’s— Genl. H. A. S. and Mrs. Dearborn, Mr Silsbee and his Son, who had come with us from Salem, Mr N. Amory,Mr Bridge, whom I had known in Russia, were of the Company. Came with the Governor, through Boston. Stopped at the Post-Office— Then at Mrs Haven’s, where we took up Mrs Eustis, who had spent the day there— At the Governor’s House in Roxbury I took leave of him, and of Mrs Eustis; and returned with my Son George to Quincy— Found Mr Marston there with my father— Mrs Adams had returned yesterday from the Governor’s exceedingly ill; but was this Evening much recovered.

24. VI:15. Visit from Coll. Trumbull. This day we took our departure, to return to Washington— I took leave of my father, with a heavy and foreboding heart. Told him I should see him again next year— Came with Mrs Adams in to Boston to Mr Cruft’s— My visit to my father has only been of 18 days, during three-fourths of which I have been called away; spending only the Nights at his house, and parts of the Morning— Mr Webster called upon me at Mr Cruft’s. I had a long Conversation with him, chiefly on political subjects— I told him of the proposal made by the Greek Agents, to Mr Rush in London, in confidence, that he might be aware of it; before the Commencement of the Session of
Congress— I also told him that I had mentioned it to Mr Fuller— I received several visitors at Mr Cruft’s, and made various calls preparatory to our departure— Dined with George at Mr John Welles’s— Mrs Adams was too unwell to go. Mr and Mrs Webster, Mr and Mrs H. Sergent, G. Blake, R. G. Amory and his daughter Catherine, and the two sons of Mr Bulfinch now on a visit to Boston were of the party— Evening at Mr Cruft’s— Mr and Mrs James H. Foster, and Coll. and Mrs B. T. Pickman were there— On the fifth of next Month, my Son George, is to be admitted as an Attorney at the Court of Common Pleas. He has been for the last year reading Law with Mr Webster; who this day, made a friendly proposal to him, which may hereafter be of service to George— But for the ensuing Winter; George proposes to go in to the Office of Mr Cook, an Attorney, in considerable practice; and with a view to acquiring the forms of practice— I leave him with an anxious feeling for his welfare and success in life.

25. V:30. We took seats in the Barry Stage— George and Charles came and saw us into the Carriage— Charles returns this day to Cambridge; entering his Senior year at the University— At seven, of the morning we left Mr Cruft’s— Went round the City and took up several passengers; among whom my brother’s second daughter, Elizabeth Coombs Adams, at her uncle Foster’s in Bulfinch Place— She is going to pass the winter with us at Washington— We came through Cambridge, Watertown, Waltham, Weston, Sudbury, Lincoln, Stow, Bolton (where we dined) Lancaster, and Sterling, to Mr Boylston’s at Princeton, 47 miles— There was some difficulty at the turn of the road to go to Mr Boylston’s house— The driver however took it— In the hurry of taking out our baggage, the travelling bag and a box were left in and on the top of the Carriage, and were taken on to Barry. We found Mr Boylston convalescent from a severe illness, but well enough to receive us with perfect cordiality.

26. VI. I rode with Mr Boylston, Morning and afternoon to Meeting and heard a Mr Perkins of Ashburnham from Romans 12.1. “I beseech you therefore brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service”—and from Proverbs 4.23. “Keep thy heart with all diligence, for out of it are the issues of life.”— Mr Perkins’s texts were to me, much more impressive than his discourses; especially that of the afternoon, and never had I greater need than at this time, of laying it to my heart. Mr Perkins who has been heretofore a lawyer in Connecticut, and has
but lately been settled as a Minister of the Gospel— He, and Mr John Erving, and Dr Brooks dined with us at Mr Boylston’s— Erving is an Uncle of G. W. Erving’s— Mr Boylston’s man Thomas went to Barry and brought back our bag and box, which I had so carelessly forgotten yesterday.

27. VI. I took a solitary morning’s walk on the road to Worcester, of about half an hour— After breakfast, rode with Mr Boylston, Mrs Adams and Elizabeth, about seven miles towards Barry, and returned— Mr Clark the Clergyman of Princeton dined with us— Mr Boylston after dinner shewed me the deposition of H. G. Otis, in the case which was tried upon the Bond— And the Bond itself; part in George Blakes, and the rest in Otis’s hand writing; to which the signature of Mr Boylston was so unaccountably, and as the verdict of the Jury found, fraudulently obtained. In the Evening, Mr Boylston gave us an entertaining account of his early travels in Greece

28. VI. At half past eight O’Clock this morning, we left Mr Boylston’s in his Carriage, and came 14 Miles to Worcester— I there met Mr W. Stedman, Dr Bancroft the Clergyman, and my old Classmate Dr Fiske— I took an Extra Carriage, and came through Oxford, Dudley and Ward, to Thompson in Connecticut— 25 Miles from Worcester— We dined at Thompson, and while waiting for dinner I read Campbell’s Pleasures of Hope; which I found at the Inn. At half past five the Stage from Boston to Hartford came in, and we took seats in it, and dismissed our Extra-Carriage from Worcester— Thompson is 50 miles from Boston and 49. from Hartford. In the Stage we met as fellow passengers the Count de Ganay, of the French Legation at Washington— Count Medem of the Russian Legation, and Coll. Beckwith, with whom I had dined last week at R. G. Amory’s. We came on 18 Miles to Ashford, where we arrived between nine and ten in the Evening; and where we pass the Night— The weather was all day showery, and the rain, in the evening on the way to Ashford quite unpleasant— The stage so full, that Ganay took his seat with the driver.

29. IV:30. Sixteen Miles to Breakfast at Mansfield— 15 thence to Hartford, where we arrived at eleven O’Clock, and immediately embarked in the Steam-Boat Oliver Ellsworth—Captain Havens— The descent down Connecticut river was new and very agreeable Scenery. The towns of Weathersfield, Middletown, East and South Haddam, and Saybrook, with many other smaller Settlements diversified the aspect of the way, and presented a variegated landscape, constantly changing and always agreeable— The weather however was chilly with occasional
Showers, and the movement of the boat so rapid, that we had not time fully to enjoy the beauties of the Country which passed in quick succession before us— The distance from Hartford to the mouth of the river is about fifty miles— At the dusk of Evening we were off Saybrook, and the prospect of a Stormy Night, alarmed some of the passengers who were desirous of laying to, for the Night. We did not however; but after landing some passengers at Saybrook, we entered the Sound— The evening was rough, but not tempestuous.

30. IV:30— We had passed Hellgate when I rose, and at five we landed at New-York, and proceeded to the City Hotel— The house was full, so that we could obtain only a small bedroom to receive our baggage— We breakfasted in the public room— We found Mrs De Wint in Broadstreet; going with one of her daughters, on a visit to my father at Quincy— She concluded to go in the Oliver Ellsworth, this afternoon— I called at Mr M’Cormick’s; and there met General North— He is going to live at or near New-London— I stopped a few minutes at the Office of the American, where I saw Mr Charles King, Mr Verplanck, Mr Wheaton, and Mr John Duer— Mrs. and Miss Dickinson, with Mr B. O. Tayloe, who is shortly to marry Miss Dickinson, were at the Hotel— At 11. we embarked in the Steam-boat Bellona, for Brunswick. Found Commodore Chauncey on board, and Mr Blunt came with us, as far as Amboy, where he landed— Just as the boat was loosened from the wharf, there was a call of enquiry, if I was on board— On my answering to my name, Mr Gurdon S. Mumford standing with another person arm in arm called out that it was an old schoolfellow of mine, who wished to take me by the hand— I thanked him, and said it would have given me great pleasure. But the boat was off; moving at the rate of ten miles an hour, and I had not time even to recognize my old Schoolmate— At Brunswick where we arrived at four in the afternoon; we left the other passengers, and I took an extra-Carriage to Bordentown— The distance is 28 miles, which our driver called 30; and after a chill Evening’s ride we reached Mr Hopkinson’s house about ten— We found there only Mrs Keating; all the rest of the family being at Philadelphia— They are there in the bustle and glory of the reception of La Fayette.

Day. The month has been consumed in a visit to my father, and my home— The time, surrendered to company, with a respite from all industry. I have sought with some success to escape from Cares, and have written scarcely any thing— I am returning with anxious and with no flattering anticipations to Washington, to finish my term of Service, and to meet the fate to which I am destined by the Disposer, who
leads the willing, drags the backward, on.
